newsitem.title: VATICAN: Pope to have appendix removed next week.
newsitem.headline: Pope to have appendix removed next week.

text.p: Pope John Paul will undergo surgery next week to remove his appendix, the Vatican announced on Monday.
It said all papal audiences would be suspended from October 7 "as a result of the Holy Father's hospitalisation".
The brief statement did not specify which day the Polish-born Pontiff, 76, would be admitted to Rome's Gemelli hospital nor when the operation would take place.
Chief Vatican spokesman Joaquin Navarro-Valls said the Pope would probably announce details himself in his midday address next Sunday after leading a beatification service at St Peter's.
Vatican sources said they expected the Pontiff to go to the Gemelli on Sunday evening.
The Rome newspaper Il Messaggero reported that the Pope would have the operation on the morning of October 7 and leave hospital on October 10 to convalesce at the Vatican.
The Vatican announced on September 14 that the Pope would shortly undergo surgery to remove his appendix.
It said then that periodic inflammation of the appendix was the cause of three bouts of "intestinal fever" which have ailed the leader of the world's Roman Catholics since Christmas.

The statement was issued by the Pope's personal physician Renato Buzzonetti following a flurry of speculation in the media about the health of the Pontiff, who has appeared increasingly fatigued and at times in discomfort in the past year.
It said other aspects of the Pope's health did not give cause for "particular concern" but made no mention of a violent trembling of the Pontiff's left hand.
Such trembling can often be a sign of Parkinson's Disease, according to medical experts.
The Pope had major abdominal surgery twice in 1981 after he was shot by Turkish gunman Mehmet Ali Agca in St Peter's Square and again in July 1992 to remove a colon tumour.
He also had hip replacement surgery in 1994 after breaking his leg in a bathroom fall and he dislocated a shoulder in 1993.
The appendix operation will be the sixth time the Pope has been taken into the Gemelli hospital since his election in 1978.
He will be admitted to a special, heavily guarded suite with its own chapel and kitchen on the 10th floor of the hospital.
Il Messaggero said the suite was protected by two armour-plated doors and bulletproof windows.
Vatican officials say the Pope is eager to be back on his feet in time to celebrate the 50th anniversary of his ordination as a priest in November.
He is due to lead a special mass to mark the occasion on November 1, the Roman Catholic feast of All Saints. Further anniversary ceremonies are scheduled later the same month.
